title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a symbol of democracy with millions of visitors annually, lacking necessary facilities. The United States Capitol Police provide excellent security, and Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for improvements. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance security and visitor experience. Congress also encourages voluntary fundraising for the project and authorizes the minting of commemorative coins. Congress authorizes the minting of commemorative coins to raise funds for the Capitol Visitor Center's construction, maintenance, and preservation. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue various coins including bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins. The minted coins include bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Secretary may mint $5 gold coins if bimetallic coins are not feasible, with specific weight, diameter, and composition. Mintage levels can be waived, and the coins minted are legal tender. The coins minted under this Act contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy, and their mintage levels may be waived. These coins are legal tender. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from various sources for minting coins under this Act. The design of the coins will be determined by the Secretary. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building, with specific inscriptions and designations required on each coin. The design will be selected by the Secretary. The design for the coins minted under this Act will feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish their role in promoting, advertising, and marketing the coins. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a role for promoting, advertising, and marketing the coins minted under this Act. If beneficial, a contract may be entered into with the Commission or a designated entity for this purpose. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in subsection (d), and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be made at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the issuance of the coins. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act at a reasonable discount. Sale prices for prepaid orders will include a surcharge established by the Secretary, not exceeding specific amounts per coin denomination. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales deposited in Capitol Preservation Fund for construction, maintenance, and preservation of Capitol Visitor Center. Passed Senate on July 30, 1999.
